issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The product is working as designed.
resolution.name: Not a Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: On the QA cloud provided to test 4.1.1 bits I tried the sample code shown below {code} require 'aws-sdk' require 'rubygems' require 'yaml' require 'logger' AWS.config({ :access_key_id => "", :secret_access_key => "", :use_ssl => false, :region => "eucalyptus", :logger => Logger.new($stdout), :log_level => :debug, :log_formatter => AWS::Core::LogFormatter.colored, :http_wire_trace => true, }) # Create ec2 = AWS::EC2.new ec2.instances.inject({}) { |m, i| m[i.id] = i.status; m } {code} It uses AWS Ruby SDK version 1.64.0 but gives 400 Bad request saying: {code} Failed to bind the following fields: Timestamp = 2015-05-05T07:07:19Z {code} The wire trace from the run: {code} POST / HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8 Accept-Encoding: Content-Length: 78 User-Agent: aws-sdk-ruby/1.64.0 ruby/2.1.1 x86_64-darwin12.0 Host: compute.h-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773 X-Amz-Date: 20150505T070719Z X-Amz-Content-Sha256: 32208b38d6dd81f0519cafe8227d9eeb5fa2c38da9ef44e0fd4319e3a0749073 Authorization: AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Credential=AKIYIBZ8ZGFGO1X8WJ5I/20150505/eucalyptus/ec2/aws4_request, SignedHeaders=content-length;content-type;host;user-agent;x-amz-content-sha256;x-amz-date, Signature=e90eaad83826c89172ad3307ad8231a9a65f98db7974a75ebe2f61ce259a456a Accept: */* ## T 10.5.1.14:53279 -> 10.111.5.1:8773 [AP] Action=DescribeInstances&Timestamp=2015-05-05T07%3A07%3A19Z&Version=2014-10-01 ##### T 10.111.5.1:8773 -> 10.5.1.14:53279 [AP] HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8 Content-Length: 284 Connection: close 400 Bad RequestFailed to bind the following fields: Timestamp = 2015-05-05T07:07:19Z Failed to bind the following fields: Timestamp = 2015-05-05T07:07:19Z ## {code} The exact code (with SSL) works on AWS EC2. Packages used to test this are: {code} rpm -qa | grep euca eucalyptus-admin-tools-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.noarch eucalyptus-cloud-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.x86_64 eucaconsole-4.1.1-0.0.5252.30.20150331gitfe545b7.el6.noarch eucalyptus-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.x86_64 eucalyptus-common-java-libs-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.x86_64 eucanetd-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.x86_64 eucalyptus-walrus-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.x86_64 eucalyptus-enterprise-storage-san-netapp-libs-4.1.1-0.0.5073.86.20150501git1bd423a.el6.x86_64 eucalyptus-service-image-0.7-0.15.12.150205gitf216f15.el6.x86_64 eucalyptus-common-java-4.1.1-0.0.23207.92.20150501git0810b0e.el6.x86_64 euca2ools-3.2.0-0.0.1660.9.20150430git3dd4d9f.el6.noarch {code} Please let me know if you have any questions. Cheers, Deependra
fields.summary: AWS Ruby SDK broken: DescribeInstances signature version 4 request with Timestamp parameter fails with binding error

comments.body:
Relevant code in Ruby SDK that adds timestamp to every request is at:

https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-ruby/blob/aws-sdk-v1/lib/aws/core/query_request_builder.rb#L26-L42

If I disable timestamp in my requests (comment out line number 33 in the above URL) I get correct response from Eucalyptus. This also does not break the AWS EC2 behaviour.

It seems AWS Ruby SDK uses signature version 4 and Timestamp is not listed as common query parameter for this signature here http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/CommonParameters.html although it is listed for signature version 2.

It is strange how AWS still works , looks like they just ignore the parameter ? Do you think it make sense to raise this with Ruby SDK folks? It seems they default to signature version 4 so it should not be used at all in the first place ?

*Note*

I had [~dshekhawat] try again while I was on the server 10.111.5.1.  I changed the logging from DEBUG to TRACE.  The following displayed in the cloud-output.log:

2015-05-05 05:41:21 TRACE 000001671 Timestamps               | Parse of timestamp '20150505T124120Z' failed for pattern 'yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'Z'', at: 0
2015-05-05 05:41:21 ERROR 000001671 NioServerHandler         | Internal Error: Failed to bind the following fields:
                          | Timestamp = 2015-05-05T12:41:20Z
{code}

The way the various AWS services handle this varies somewhat, but ignoring unnecessary Signature and Timestamp parameters in requests with v4 signatures seems to be a common thread.

IAM's application logic ignores requests it doesn't recognize, its authentication handler checks short-circuit, and it checks v4 signatures first, so if the service receives a request with a v4 Authorization header it will blithely ignore any Signature, Timestamp, or SignatureVersion parameters that happen to be present.

{code}
% bin/euare-usergetattributes --region us-east-1
2015-05-06 14:27:15,828 DEBUG   IAM request method: POST
2015-05-06 14:27:15,828 DEBUG   IAM request url:    https://iam.amazonaws.com/
2015-05-06 14:27:15,828 DEBUG   IAM request header: Authorization: AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Credential=AKIAIPAN6357JVMJGZMQ/20150506/us-east-1/iam/aws4_request, SignedHeaders=content-length;content-type;host;x-amz-content-sha256;x-amz-date, Signature=56359be5d071b6260a627d86b77d43c241452dd3435a481a615b69888c2d6e92
2015-05-06 14:27:15,828 DEBUG   IAM request header: Content-Length: 91
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request header: Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request header: Host: iam.amazonaws.com
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request header: User-Agent: euca2ools/3.2.0-24-g1003408 (CPython 2.7.8; Linux 3.19.5-200.fc21.x86_64; x86_64) requestbuilder/0.3.0-pre1-7-g77a0cfb requests/2.5.3
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request header: X-Amz-Content-SHA256: becc3f2d41fb321ea3c4deb87a0614f93f9773c50ba18c962dc72057bfaf5f35
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request header: X-Amz-Date: 20150506T212715Z
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request data:   Action: GetUser
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request data:   Signature: foobar
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request data:   SignatureVersion: foobar
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request data:   Timestamp: foobar
2015-05-06 14:27:15,829 DEBUG   IAM request data:   Version: 2010-05-08
2015-05-06 14:27:16,274 DEBUG   IAM response time: 0.444 seconds
2015-05-06 14:27:16,274 INFO    IAM response status: 200
2015-05-06 14:27:16,274 DEBUG   IAM response header: content-length: 483
2015-05-06 14:27:16,274 DEBUG   IAM response header: content-type: text/xml
2015-05-06 14:27:16,275 DEBUG   IAM response header: date: Wed, 06 May 2015 21:27:15 GMT
2015-05-06 14:27:16,275 DEBUG   IAM response header: x-amzn-requestid: aafe95ea-f436-11e4-bff3-8576cb8babef
{code}

By contrast, EC2 checks version 0/1/2 signatures first and its application logic uses parameter whitelisting.  This means that if a request contains a SignatureVersion any Authorization headers that may be present are ignored and the authorization check proceeds entirely on the basis of a version 0/1/2 signature.  If a SignatureVersion is _not_ present then any Signature or Timestamp parameters that happen to be present are ignored because they are already whitelisted.

{code}
% bin/euca-describe-regions --region us-east-1
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request method: POST
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request url:    https://ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: Authorization: AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Credential=AKIAIPAN6357JVMJGZMQ/20150506/us-east-1/ec2/aws4_request, SignedHeaders=content-length;content-type;host;x-amz-content-sha256;x-amz-date, Signature=da55c321467494f0d84eed1fe96d31a777e366ac215e418f07fc4af7e577ed37
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: Content-Length: 99
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: Host: ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: User-Agent: euca2ools/3.2.0-24-g1003408 (CPython 2.7.8; Linux 3.19.5-200.fc21.x86_64; x86_64) requestbuilder/0.3.0-pre1-7-g77a0cfb requests/2.5.3
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: X-Amz-Content-SHA256: 7061f3892398d2effa64035e5e03dcb0e277450f6d7c92f9e322658dac8b0060
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request header: X-Amz-Date: 20150506T213300Z
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request data:   Action: DescribeRegions
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request data:   Signature: foobar
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request data:   SignatureVersion: foobar
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request data:   Timestamp: foobar
2015-05-06 14:33:00,302 DEBUG   EC2 request data:   Version: 2014-06-15
2015-05-06 14:33:00,661 DEBUG   EC2 response time: 0.358 seconds
2015-05-06 14:33:00,661 ERROR   EC2 response status: 400
2015-05-06 14:33:00,661 DEBUG   EC2 response header: cneonction: close
2015-05-06 14:33:00,661 DEBUG   EC2 response header: date: Wed, 06 May 2015 21:32:59 GMT
2015-05-06 14:33:00,661 DEBUG   EC2 response header: server: AmazonEC2
2015-05-06 14:33:00,661 DEBUG   EC2 response header: transfer-encoding: chunked
...
euca2ools.exceptions.AWSError: (400, 'Bad Request', 'InvalidParameterValue', 'Value (foobar) for parameter Timestamp is invalid. Must be in ISO8601 format.')
{code}
[~viglesias] suggests that QA should have simple tests against latest Ruby (and other) SDK(s) so that we notice these issues quickly.

[~dshekhawat] On 4.0 This works with the aws-sdk-euca (1.8.5)? Are you using aws-sdk-v1? {code:xml} eucalyptus 4.2.0 [mmunn:~/Downloads]gem list | grep sdk aws-sdk-euca (1.8.5) [mmunn:~/Downloads]ruby -v ruby 2.1.2p95 (2014-05-08 revision 45877) [x86_64-linux] [mmunn:~/Downloads]ruby -v ruby 2.1.2p95 (2014-05-08 revision 45877) [x86_64-linux] [mmunn:~/Downloads] [mmunn:~/Downloads]ruby test.rb Digest::Digest is deprecated; use Digest opening connection to 10.111.5.68:8773... opened <- "POST /services/compute/ HTTP/1.1\r\nContent-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8\r\nContent-Length: 219\r\nUser-Agent: aws-sdk-ruby/1.8.5 ruby/2.1.2 x86_64-linux\r\nAccept-Encoding: gzip;q=1.0,deflate;q=0.6,identity;q=0.3\r\nAccept: */*\r\nHost: 10.111.5.68:8773\r\n\r\n" -> "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\n" -> "Content-Length: 1367\r\n" -> "Content-Type: application/xml; charset=UTF-8\r\n" -> "\r\n" reading 1367 bytes... -> "8764d687-24e8-4a93-af8a-a0baa05b8045r-bf890973000656861300sg-8d867126defaulti-965ddc6femi-c0ab4e5916running10.111.30.9010.111.30.86NORMAL: -- []0m1.small2015-05-26T20:09:59.720Zonedisabled10.111.30.9010.111.30.86sg-8d867126defaultx86_64instance-store/dev/sda1hvmeuca:node10.111.5.181 "tagSet>" read 1367 bytes Conn keep-alive D, [2015-05-26T13:16:03.776247 #11651] DEBUG -- : [AWS EC2 200 0.302553 0 retries] describe_instances() Digest::Digest is deprecated; use Digest <- "POST /services/compute/ HTTP/1.1\r\nContent-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8\r\nContent-Length: 241\r\nUser-Agent: aws-sdk-ruby/1.8.5 ruby/2.1.2 x86_64-linux\r\nAccept-Encoding: gzip;q=1.0,deflate;q=0.6,identity;q=0.3\r\nAccept: */*\r\nHost: 10.111.5.68:8773\r\n\r\n" -> "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\n" -> "Content-Length: 1367\r\n" -> "Content-Type: application/xml; charset=UTF-8\r\n" -> "\r\n" reading 1367 bytes... -> "2a718680-2715-4703-b2d3-71d5f1d140c9r-bf890973000656861300sg-8d867126defaulti-965ddc6femi-c0ab4e5916running10.111.30.9010.111.30.86NORMAL: -- []0m1.small2015-05-26T20:09:59.720Zonedisabled10.111.30.9010.111.30.86sg-8d867126defaultx86_64instance-store/dev/sda1hvmeuca:node10.111.5.181" read 1367 bytes Conn keep-alive D, [2015-05-26T13:16:03.956821 #11651] DEBUG -- : [AWS EC2 200 0.170714 0 retries] describe_instances(:instance_ids=>["i-965ddc6f"]) [mmunn:~/Downloads] {code}

Here is the ruby I am using:
{code}
require 'aws-sdk'
require 'rubygems'
require 'yaml'
require 'logger'

AWS.config({
      :access_key_id => "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX",
      :secret_access_key => "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX",
      :ec2_endpoint => '10.111.5.68',
      :ec2_service_path => '/services/compute/',
      :ec2_port => 8773,
      :use_ssl => false,
      :logger => Logger.new($stdout),
      :log_level => :debug,
      :log_formatter => AWS::Core::LogFormatter.colored,
      :http_wire_trace => true,
})

# Create
ec2 = AWS::EC2.new
ec2.instances.inject({}) { |m, i| m[i.id] = i.status; m }

{code}

Hi [~mmunn1], I am using AWS Ruby SDK 1.64.0 (which is old and deprecated according to AWS also called AWS Ruby SDK v1) but my end goal is to make sure we have support for AWS Ruby SDK v2 which is current and supported by AWS.
[~dshekhawat] How were you able top connect to eucalyptus without using aws-sdk-euca (1.8.5) ? I am not sure we were ever able to connect/support using an unmodified aws-sdk?

[~dshekhawat] Can you provide me with the output from "gem list" on the machine where you ran the sample code in the bug description? There is no endpoint information in the ruby script you used? I am not sure how you connected to eucalyptus at all as you only gave was the region = "eucalyptus".

AWS Ruby SDK 1.8.5 is 2 years old and IMHO we shouldn't be testing with it. In order to use AWS Ruby SDK 1.64.0 please install the appropriate gem and then modify the endpoints json file located at {{/Users/jeevanullas/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.1.1/gems/aws-sdk-v1-1.64.0}}

For your reference I have uploaded the JSON that I used here:

https://gist.github.com/jeevanullas/d2135a709067fbb16918

I created an "eucalyptus" region in the JSON file as shown below:

https://gist.github.com/jeevanullas/d2135a709067fbb16918#file-endpoints-json-L180-L221

and also ensure this region is known to the services as shown below:

https://gist.github.com/jeevanullas/d2135a709067fbb16918#file-endpoints-json-L1529-L1816

Please let me know. This requirement of having Ruby SDK 1.64.0 is very critical because AWS Ruby SDK 1.64.0 is hard coded dependency for Bosh (the tool used to deploy Cloudfoundry PaaS on AWS and Eucalyptus).

As said earlier long term we should ensure Eucalyptus work without modifications against Ruby SDK v2

The following works with no errors 'as is' in Eucalyptus 4.1.2 with no modifications on the Ruby side or the Eucalyptus side in Ruby V2: {code} require 'aws-sdk' require 'rubygems' require 'yaml' require 'logger' Aws.config[:http_wire_trace] = true, Aws.config[:logger] = Logger.new($stdout) Aws.config[:log_level] = 'debug' Aws.config[:http_wire_trace] = true Aws.config.update({ credentials: Aws::Credentials.new( EC2_ACCESS_KEY, EC2_SECRET_KEY), }) client = Aws::EC2::Client.new( region: 'eucalyptus', endpoint:EC2_URL) ec2 = Aws::EC2::Resource.new(client: client) puts ec2.instances.inject({}) { |m, i| m[i.id] = i.state.name; m } {code} Notice the difference in the Instance API http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdkforruby/api/Aws/EC2/Instance.html OutPut {code} [mmunn:~/Downloads]ruby vv.rb opening connection to 10.111.5.63:8773... opened <- "POST /services/compute HTTP/1.1\r\nContent-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; As the aws ruby v2 sdk works with no modification I am closing this as not a bug.

For production systems where going to the latest version is not possible, what is the recommended workaround? We are using Red Hat CloudForms (CentOS ManageIQ) which comes bundled with Ruby v1. Upgrading to v2 will not be possible without a full QA cycle from Red Hat which will take some time.

[~jgallucci32],

Did you try the workaround mentioned [above|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-10807?focusedCommentId=86059&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-86059]?  

In short, there is a cloud property {{bootstrap.webservices.unknown_parameter_handling}}, which can be changed to handle unknown parameters.
{code}
# euctl bootstrap.webservices.unknown_parameter_handling -s 
bootstrap.webservices.unknown_parameter_handling = Request unknown parameter handling (default|ignore|error).

## default value ##
# euctl bootstrap.webservices.unknown_parameter_handling
bootstrap.webservices.unknown_parameter_handling = default
{code}
As you can see, in Eucalyptus 4.1.1 and greater, the default value for this cloud property is {{default}}.  Did you change this property to {{ignore}} and are still seeing the same issues?
{code}
# euctl bootstrap.webservices.unknown_parameter_handling=ignore
{code}
If so, please reopen this ticket so we can investigate further into this issue.
